column2: 2015 at 1 35 pm Very good summary  Thank  One simple point  The reason for taking the log  in Logistic Regression is to make the equation linear
column3: I e
column4: easy to solve  Sunil Ray says  August 21
column5: 2015 at 5 21 am Thanks Dalila    Borun Chowdhury says  April 21
column6: 2016 at 8 48 am That s not the reason for taking the log  The underlying assumption in logistic regression is that the probability is governed by a step function whose argument is linear in the attributes  First of all the assumption of linearity or otherwise introduces bias  However
column7: logistic regression being a parametric model some bias is inevitable  The reason to choose a linear relationship is not because its easy to solve but because a higher order polynomial introduces higher bias and one would not like to do so without good reason  Now coming to the choice of log
column8: it is just a convention  Basically
column9: once we have decided to go with a linear model
column10: in the case of one attribute we model the probability by p  fsuch that p 0 and p 0  It so happens that this is satisfied by p  exp    which can be re_written as log     a x  b While I am at it
column11: it may be useful to talk about another point  One should ask is why we don t use least square method  The reason is that a yes no choice is a Bernoulli random variable and thus we estimate the probability according to maximum likelihood wrt Bernoulli process  For linear regression the assumption is that the residuals around the  true  function are distributed according to a normal distribution and the maximum likelihood estimate for a normal distribution amounts to the least square method  So deep down linear regression and logistic regression both use maximum likelihood estimates  Its just that they are max likelihoods according to different distributions

column8: you can remove it via y   0   x  Interactions are specified with either   or     y   x1   x2 is equivalent to y   x1   x2   x1   x2  Hope this helps

column2: 2015 at 7 00 pm This is a great resource overall and surely the product of a lot of work  Just a note as I go through this
column3: your comment on Logistic Regression not actually being regression is in fact wrong  It maps outputs to a continuous variable bound between 0 and 1 that we regard as probability  it makes classification easy but that is still an extra step that requires the choice of a threshold which is not the main aim of Logistic Regression  As a matter of fact it falls under the umbrella of Generalized Libear Models as the glm R package hints it in your code example  I thought this was interesting to note so as not to forget that logistic regression output is richer than 0 or 1  Thanks for the great article overall
